awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Innovative Glass Inspection for Advanced Semiconductor Packaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to enhance the semiconductor industry.  The development of the proposed technology will advance the creation of and reduce the cost of high-quality electronic products such as smartphones, laptops, televisions, AR/VR devices, 5G components, and data storage devices that will be commercially available to individual consumers.  This research project will have a substantial societal benefit on the revitalization of the US semiconductor industry by creating more American jobs, boosting national security and reducing the vulnerability of semiconductor devices to tampering and counterfeiting and giving the US a competitive edge in the global market.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will create technology that will advance the creation of high-quality electronic products that will be commercially available to individual consumers.  The increasing use of glass panels for semiconductor packaging presents an opportunity to develop technology which will perform full surface inspection of these panels for defects.  No nano-particle inspection technology exists for ≥300 mm glass substrates for particles ≤300 nm in diameter, such as those used in advanced semiconductor packaging.   The successful development of this highly sensitive process control technology will address these glass inspection pain points, with substantial improvements in yield for semiconductor packaging companies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Innovative Glass Inspection for Advanced Semiconductor Packaging


Lumina Instruments developed a novel optical scanning technology for high-throughput, full surface inspection of glass panels with sub-nanometer thickness sensitivity and detection capabilities to 5 Angstroms. Several high technology industries including semiconductor processing, packaging and AR/VR applications are seeking solutions for detecting edge defects, TGV (Through Glass Via) defects in thin glass panels, very small particles, and organic contamination on glass. This research developed a glass inspection tool that measures the polarization rotation produced by a transparent film on the top surface of a transparent substrate and measure the dark field (scatter) of nanoparticles from the top surface of a transparent substrate over a 100 mm field of view. The scanning polarization technology was combined with a high-speed edge defect inspection technology to produce a complete glass inspection solution. This Phase II project also developed algorithms to scan, detect, and classify the Through-glass-Via (TGV) on patterned glass substrates into various categories: good, bad, and missing. The successful development of Lumina’s highly sensitive process control technology will address these glass inspection pain points, with substantial customer opportunities. By allowing rapid, accurate full surface inspection of glass wafers and panels, Luminas’ technology will address the limitations of existing process control tools at a low cost of ownership and enable next-generation integration of glass in high technology semiconductor packaging processes.  During the first six-month period we focused on developing hardware and software to detect 50 micron and greater chips on round wafers and glass panels.  Two approaches were taken: one for chip detection on round wafers and a separate approach for chips on glass panels. We developed a hardware and software edge chip detection approach that can be used in parallel with the defect scan of transparent round wafers. The advantage of this approach is that the chip measurement can be made at the same time that the wafer is scanned for other defects which are present on the flat surface of the wafer.  We evaluated various optical channels for detecting edge chips and arrived at the conclusion that the bright field signal gives the best performance for chip detection. During the second phase of the grant we developed and delivered an inspection tool for the full surface inspection of glass panels up to 600x600 mm.  The optical design of the optics for this inspection tool was developed during an NSF Phase 1 grant, and the platform with software was developed during this part of the Phase 2 grant.
